title: Abdominoscrotal Hydrocele: An Uncommon Cause of Abdominoscrotal Cystic Swelling
patient: A 27-year-old male patient presented in the General Surgery OPD of Acharya Vinoba Bhave Hospital in 2019 with bilateral scrotal and lower abdominal swelling (), which was insidious in onset with dull aching dragging pain. There was no previous history of trauma or fever. On physical examination, bilateral hydrocele was present, and both swellings were nonreducible, transluminant, and fluctuant. Abdominal swelling was extending up to the umbilicus, and cross fluctuation was present with left side hydrocele, raising the possibility of left-sided ASH. The CECT abdomen revealed a large intercommunicating homogeneous hourglass-shaped fluid collection involving the lower abdomen and left scrotum (), confirming the diagnosis. The patient underwent uneventful, complete excision of the sac through the left inguinoscrotal approach ().
